description.narrative: In Burundi, this Reconstruction programme will focus on the following outcomes: Outcome 1. Increased mutual respect and inclusive informal and formal cooperation (including cross border cooperation) among families and communities in the Ruzizi Valley, which has been linked to accountable forms of local/regional in country and cross border governance. Outcome 2. Inclusive improved food security and participation in cross border value chains, with strengthened local governance (including cross-border governance) and developed links with the overall development efforts of the (re-emerging) legitimate government structures, with specific attention for youth, demobilised combatants and marginalized women.

The proposed Promoting Human Security in Ruzizi Valley Programme foresees to work during the four years with some 16,800 smallholder families (102.000 persons), which is about one third of the population of the Ruzizi Valley part of Cibitoke Province on the Burundi side and the opposite part of South Kivu Province of the DRC. Special attention is given to high risk groups of 900 youth and former combatants and 1080 marginalized women.

ZOA proposes this Promoting Human Security in Ruzizi Valley Programme, to enhance stability and security in the border area between Burundi and the DRC as preconditions for people to rebuild their lives and livelihoods and contribute to structural poverty reduction. The programme will contribute to legitimate government, build local government capacity and will create a visible peace dividend.

activity-date.narrative: The project received initial approval by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs on 28th June 2012 for a total amount of 60% of the proposed budget at the time of submission in March 2012. ZOA was then asked to submit a revised project plan by latest 15th September 2012. The Ministry notified ZOA of the approval of the revised plan on 16th November 2012, after which ZOA started implementation of the project. ZOA found it best to not start the revised project immediately after submission in September 2012 so not to run the risk of beginning project work on a wrong footing, we considered the operational risks of starting the project without having received the donor’s ultimate directions, too high. Therefore, we could only start full project preparations in second half of November.

policy-marker.narrative: The main objective of this programme is: enhanced stability and security as preconditions for people to rebuild their lives and strengthen their livelihood strategies through: 1) building mutual respect and inclusive informal and formal cooperation and 2) inclusive improved food security and participation in cross border value chains.

description.narrative: Community based land demarcation facilitated and in Burundi also local government (Commune level) capacitated for official cadastre land registration
4200 smallholder households in the programme area have been facilitated to obtain clearly demarcated and locally undisputed land borders over the programme period of 4 years.

comment.narrative: Activities not yet started
Activities were cancelled in Burundi.
Planned for 2014

description.narrative: The Local Government authorities on the Burundi side of the Ruzizi Valley (Commune level) have been capacitated to operate decentralised cadastre services over the programme period of 4 years, issuing land ownership titles.

comment.narrative: Activities were cancelled in Burundi.
This activity planned for Burundi was not achieved due to postponement of the Swiss Cooperation\'s project until mid 2014.

description.narrative: Cross-border multi-stakeholder processes related to economic and social development established, round table platform organisation capacitated and resulting cross border projects supported.

Per indentified subject matter cross-border roundtable, at least two projects per year will have been identified and supported which will have a regional character and deal with issues as mentioned above, such as land allocation, trade development, etc., for an average total value of EUR 48,000 each year (as of 2013).

comment.narrative: N/A
Two projects per year will have been identified and supported
2 specific rountables were organized jointly by congolese and burundian teams, one in the cross border trade, the second on the control of cassava, maize and banana diseases in the Ruzizi Valley.

3 specific rountables were organized jointly by congolese and burundian teams, one in the cross border trade, the second on the control of cassava, maize and banana diseases and the third on the climate change effects in the Ruzizi Valley.
Two projects per year will have been identified and supported

Even if the global round table was not organized, some specific activities were proposed to be achieved in country as result of the workshops organized in each country in preparation of the Global round table.
Two projects per year will have been identified and supported

The organization of the global round table was postponed in 2014 given the violent conflicts that have occurred in the Ruzizi valley in July-August 2013. Preparatory activities for the round tables are planned to begin in February 2014.

description.narrative: One overall cross-border multi-stakeholder Round Table and at least one subject matter cross-border multi-stakeholder round table established and capacitated per year during the four-year programme period to identify, discuss and address at least two cross-border issues per year for improving stability and economic and social development in the programme area.

comment.narrative: N/A: Activities not yet started
One overall cross-border multi-stakeholder Round Table and one subject matter cross-border multi-stakeholder round table per year

All planned preliminary activities were achieved and all conditions were already met prior to the organization of the global round table but insecurity that has emerged on the eve of this event, was the main lock to its running.
One overall cross-border multi-stakeholder Round Table and one subject matter cross-border multi-stakeholder round table per year

No Global roundtable was organized, this has followed the recommendations from the report of the consultant recruited for the global Round Table in 2014, who suggested (regarding the contextual difficulties) to organize specific roundtables (only) to lead the implementation of some cross-border specific activities
One overall cross-border multi-stakeholder Round Table and one subject matter cross-border multi-stakeholder round table per year

Planned Overall roundtables were not organized due to the inter-tribal tensions after the successive massacres in the village of Mutarule in 2014 and 2015. But separated workshops were organized and focus groups conducted which resulted in a common vision on the cross-border matters.
One overall cross-border multi-stakeholder Round Table and one subject matter cross-border multi-stakeholder round table per year

The organization of the global round table was postponed in 2014 given the violent conflicts that have occurred in the Ruzizi valley in July-August 2013. Preparatory activities for the round tables are planned to begin in February 2014.

description.narrative: Improved capacity of partner organisations to contribute to the above mentioned outputs and outcome.

At least 80% of the agreed capacity building measures with the three key programme partner NGOs will have been implemented. This concerns the capacities needed to ‘deliver on objectives’44 in relation to objective 1 and its underlying outputs, such as: skills for training in reconciliation and mediation, skills for strengthening community based capacities, conflict and gender sensitive planning, etc.

comment.narrative: N/A

3 measures out of 6 achieved in DRC regarding the capacity building plan and 2/3 achieved in Burundi. The trainings were based on the capacity building plan 2014. The figures in 2013 were not based on the capacity building plan but on the initiatives undertaken.
This is the average of the implemented capacity building activities for all implementation years.

description.narrative: Inclusive improved food security and participation in cross border value chains, with strengthened local governance (including cross-border governance) and developed links with the overall development efforts of the (re-emerging) legitimate government structures, with specific attention for youth, demobilised combatants and marginalized women.

At least 6720 (40%) smallholder households (out of the total of 16,800), 360(40%) underemployed youth and demobilised combatants (out of the total of 900) and 432(40%) marginalized women (out of the total of 1080) show improvement in a composite household food security score, moving to a next higher category level of food security over the total period of 4 years as compared to the baseline.

comment.narrative: Baseline was realized during harvest period. Intake available in nov-dec 2013

In Burundi, the score for the small farmers was appreciated at 39.51, 36.32 for the marginalized women and 37.61 for the underemployed youth and demobilised combatants. See narrative report for more explanation

This is the result of the project mini-survey conducted in April 2016 in Burundi among project beneficiaries. In Burundi the score for the small farmers is 44.5, the score for the marginalized women is 43.8 and that of the underemployed youth and demobilised combatants is 46.4.

This is the result of the the project annual survey conducted in November 2015 in Burundi among project beneficiaries. In Burundi the score for the small farmers is 42.3, the score for the marginalized women is 35.6 and that of the underemployed youth and demobilised combatants is 39.1.
Improvement in a composite household food security score
To be collected during the mid term review

description.narrative: Increased capacity for improved productivity and storage of food-crops plus two for smallholder important value chains selected and analysed43, with special attention for the cross border aspects in them, and plan made for Value Chain Development of these selected two Chains, and actors facilitated and capacitated to actually develop these two value chains.

At least 40% of the 16,800 households can show at least three of the following five improvement measures: improved soil fertility, better seed varieties and improved farming practices (sowing, weeding), improved storage practices, improved marketing by the end of the four year programme period.

comment.narrative: 2252 households out of 8400 in BDI are able to demonstrate the adoption of, at least, tree of the five improvement measures in the agricultural season A & B 2015. (please note that the 8400 households in the indicator refer to ALL project beneficiaries, whereas the beneficiaries are sub-divided per output reported in the narrative)

3500 Farmers households received agricultural inputs during the year 2013 in Burundi. From that number, 3500 (100%) have received training on improved farming techniques and have adopted the following improvement measures: planting of the improved seed, planting in rows and weeding of the fields.
No change was done to these figures.

These households were able to demonstrate the adoption of, at least, three of the following five improvement measures in the agricultural season 2014: improved soil fertility, better seed varieties and improved farming practices (sowing, weeding), improved storage practices, improved marketing. In Burundi data were collected to 1000 farmers supported with beans and maize in 2014. In 2013, there was a mistake in the calculation, because then we just counted the number of farmers who were trained. More explanation is given in the narrative report.

description.narrative: Relevant actors capacitated to implement at least four key issues of the two value chain development plans over the four years of the programme. Depending on what will be the content of these Value Chain development plans, these can be matters such as: the increase in number and capacity of savings and credit groups or micro-finance institutions (MFIs), the improvement of input supply system for agricultural crops (timely availability of quality seeds and fertilizer/pesticides), the connection of in country and cross-border markets for inputs or crop outputs, the household or community level storage capacity for crops, the crop processing capacity, etc

comment.narrative: 175 commmunity mobilisers in BDI, continued to be capacitated to implement activities related to chosen value chains.

175 commmunity mobilisers in BDI, continued to be capacitated to implement the selected value chain development activities. Activities included training & capacity building for production, storage, precessing and marketing.
In Burundi, 175 community mobilisers for the small farmers were strengthened.
No change was done to these figures.

description.narrative: Two value chains selected and value chain development plans prepared and validated in a participatory way with the stakeholders concerned within the first year of the programme.

comment.narrative: 5 chain values (2 in DRC and 3 in BDI) were selected and their development plans developped.
A value chain study was undertaken, action plan will be made once the report is available (Feb 2015)
In Burundi, maize, beans and cassava were selected by producers for value chain analyses.

480 underemployed youth and demobilised combatants and 600 marginalized women capacitated for marketable income generating activities and/or animal husbandry over the 4 year programme period (DRC + BDI)

526 underemployed youth / 631 marginalized women In Burundi, 631 women out of 300, and 521 young people of 240 were identified along the 6 villages of Buganda District and grouped into 28 associations. The beneficiaries are trained in various trades, including: small scale trading, tailoring, carpentry, brick making, beekeeping, welding, hairdressing, repairing bikes.

description.narrative: Increased mutual respect and inclusive informal and formal cooperation (including cross border cooperation) among families and communities in the Ruzizi Valley, which has been linked to accountable forms of local and regional in country and cross border governance.

20% reduced number of incidents of violent behaviour between parties that have a land and/or family conflict as experienced by villagers in the programme villages over 3 years period in relation to baseline. This concerns incidents among agriculturists, incidents between animal keepers and agriculturists and other types of conflicts.

comment.narrative: Average number of reported conflicts in the past 12 months
20% decrease in number of incidents of violent behaviour.
No annual survey was organized to collect data for this outcome indicator. It will be measured during the mid-term review in 2014.

description.narrative: At least 40% of the 1080 marginalized women and 900 underemployed youth and demobilised combatants, who at the beginning of the programme were not a member of any groups, will have become an active member of at least one group with economic or education activities within three years after the baseline is taken.

comment.narrative: During the baseline these groups were not yet identified and they were not part of any group.

1018 Marginalized women out of 540, and 350 young people out of 450 were identified and grouped into 83 VSLA (Village Savings and Loans Associations) in DR Congo, to be strengthened before being supported in Income Generating Activities by the first half of 2014. In Burundi, 631 women out of 540, and 521 young people out of 540 were identified along the 6 villages of Buganda District and were grouped into 28 associations. The achievement of this indicator on both sides of the border is zero because no income generating activity or education have started in the groups formed in 2013.
In Burundi 583 (instead of the planned 450) underemployed youth and demobilised combatants and 832 marginalized women (instead of the planned 540) have become active members of the VSLA.

In Burundi the number of marginalized women reached 1010 out instead of the planned 540 and 469 underemployed youth and demobilised combatants instead of the planned 450. Compared with 2014, the latter number reduced in Burundi due to political instability in the country
No changes since end of 2015.

description.narrative: No progress yet on outcome/output level as in description due to a revision of the project plan in September 2012. The work in the project for which the costs were eligible, started from 1st July 2012. In July and August the original project plan was revised on request of the external donor, to accommodate the partial approval. The partial approval had the nature of a budget cut that was to be entered into the project plan by designing a revised plan at a lower cost, meanwhile not altering the character and heart of the project. As a result of the 40% budget cut, the number of beneficiary households was reduced by 40%, to a total of 16,800 households (8,400 in each of Burundi and DR Congo), representing approximately 75,600 people. The number of unemployed youth and demobilized ex-combatants on which the project will focus was reduced by 40% also, to the new number of 900; the number of marginalised women, in particular childmothers, divorced women and young widows, was reduced to 1080. The project will now target 450 youths and 540 marginalized women on each side of the border. The nature of our intervention was not changed.

title.narrative: Not applicable for this annual report: see narrative above

description.narrative: School teachers, church leaders and other leaders of existing civil society structures (at least 50% women) trained to produce a curriculum on values, causes of conflicts, negotiation and mediation, strengthened position of women as actors in peace-building and in reconstruction and trained on how to use this in how to use this curriculum in their ‘lessons’ and training of their own groups.

In every participating village every year at least two of local trained teachers/leaders, of whom at least 50% women, report back about at least two examples of new elements prepared in the curriculum for trainings that they use to give for their own groups: new elements that deal with values, causes of conflicts, negotiation or mediation, and two good examples of how these items were dealt with in their lessons and training of their own classes/groups in their villages.

comment.narrative: N/A
Every year at least two of local trained teachers/leaders of whom 50% women
46 teachers & 12 religious / civil society leaders were trained. Among them were 28 women in 6 villages.
Every year at least two of local trained teachers/leaders of whom 50% women

60 local teachers, religious and other local leaders were trained on conflict prevention through the DELTA method. 22 of them have reported back on the new elements prepared in the curriculum for trainings (causes of conflicts, negotiation or mediation), intended to peace clubs initated at the school level. 6 villages in BDI were targeted.
Every year at least two of local trained teachers/leaders of whom 50% women
Planned for 2014

description.narrative: Small inclusion and mutual respect promoting community projects proposed, approved and monitored and advised during implementation, with special attention for proposals from underemployed youth (among whom demobilised combatants) and from women groups among whom marginalized women.

12 community groups, among which at least 3 women groups, have proposed 18 small projects per year that are in line with the two outcomes of this programme. One of the criteria for approval is having a substantial ‘own’ contribution in the project.

comment.narrative: N/A
3 new community projects were proposed in 2014 in Burundi

In Burundi 19 micro-projects out of 9 planned were proposed, including: 4 small bridges, 10 houses of marginalized women, 2 inter-village roads to be rehabilitated, and 3 communal VIP latrines to be constructed.
In total, 31 instead of 27 planned were proposed in Burundi.

description.narrative: At least 18 proposals per year for a total value of EUR 150,000 each year approved and implemented (as of 2013), with close monitoring by ZOA and ZOA partner organisations.

comment.narrative: N/A
18 proposals per year approved and implemented

From the list of the proposed and approved community projects mentioned above, 19 were identified and only one on bridge reconstruction was implemented and monitored by ZOA and ZOA partner organizations during 2013 in Burundi.
18 proposals per year improved and implemented

From the projects proposed in 2013 and 2014, 29 were funded in 2014, 26 completely achieved in 2014 and 3 are under way until 2015. The total target for the whole project period for the two countries is 54 projects.
18 proposals per year approved and implemented

description.narrative: Structures of Community Governance capacitated to include human security in their work and get a higher women participation.

In every participating village every year at least one of the structures of community governance has been capacitated and show increased awareness and skills in including ‘new’ ‘human security’ issues to be dealt with by this structure. This can be any kind of issue that deals with structural decreasing of causes of conflict, exclusion or instability.

comment.narrative: N/A

24 Local governance structures were identified in 6 villages of Buganda District in Burundi. These committes are already operational and are are being strengthened in governance, conflict resolution, and the Delta strategy.

24 out of 24 continue to be reinforced on notions of accountability, transparency, good governance, non-violent conflict management, financial management, human rights, restorative justice, monitoring in cases of violation of human rights and they use these skills in their daily work.

24 out of 24 continue to be reinforced on notions of accountability, transparency, good governance, non-violent conflict management, financial management, human rights, restorative justice, monitoring in cases of violation of human rights and they use these skills in their daily work.

In total, 24 local governance structures in Burundi, were reinforced on notions of accountability, transparency, good governance, non-violent conflict management, financial management, human rights, restorative justice, monitoring in cases of violation of human rights. But six structures (peace committees) have demonstrated the increased capacity in conflict resolution in Burundi.

description.narrative: At least 50% of the concerning community governance structures have been enabled to have at least 50% of women membership over the four years of the programme.

comment.narrative: N/A: Structures did not exist/were not identified before baseline
In 50% of the concerning community governance structures there is at least 50% of women membership.

12 out of 24 community governance structures have been enabled to have at least 50% of women membership in Burundi. There was miscalculation in 2013 on Burundi side, the number of committees with 50% was 12 instead of 17. The calculation was wrong for the last year in BDI, because only the forum of women and the peace committees have 50% of women.

description.narrative: Traditional leaders that traditionally handle conflicts have increased capacity in local level gender and conflict sensitive conflict handling methods.

At least 50% of the at least 60 traditional leaders that have participated in the training during the four-year programme period report back on examples of successful application of increased reconciliation and mediation skills in dealing with local conflicts over the four years of the programme.

comment.narrative: N/A

26/26 traditional leaders trained in Burundi, have reported to have succeeded to resolve local conflicts through the reconciliation and mediation techniques. All resolved conflicts were reported to ZOA\'s project implmenting partners.
26/26 traditional leaders trained in Burundi, have reported to have succeeded to resolve local conflicts through the reconciliation and mediation techniques.
26/26 traditional leaders trained in Burundi, have reported to have succeeded to resolve local conflicts through the reconciliation and mediation techniques.
In Burundi, 26 traditional leaders reinforced in conflict management skills were able to resolve 63 cases of conflicts during 2013.

description.narrative: Women gained literacy and numeracy skills.

75% of 2400 participating women (BDI+DRC) among whom at least 300 marginalized women, gained literacy and numeracy over 4 years through functional adult literacy. These groups can(like others) also propose projects in the system of output 1.4’

75% of 2400 = 1800 = 900 per country
In Burundi, 600 women out of a target of 900 have been identified and are being trained in 18 literacy classes.
75% of 2400 = 1800 = 900 per country
This is the number of marginalized women who have completed the literacy course.

This is the total number of the women who have finalized the adult literacy course, from the women enrolled in 2013 (600) and those enrolled in 2014 (720). In BDI the identified number in 2014 is still in course. All of the identified are marginalized women.
